summary_md: Last round produced a short, complete proof for d=3 building on the provided d=2 file. The proof splits into two cases: (A) some coordinate slice (e.g. z=t) contains ≥2 points — apply the d=2 theorem on that slice and lift uniqueness to 3D because c_3 records the fixed coordinate; (B) every slice has ≤1 point — order by that coordinate and the edge between the top two levels has a uniquely determined lower-corner coordinate, hence a unique color. An alternate view factors color counts as A_+·A_− (product of witnesses), which gives the same conclusions and suggests an induction to general d. Citations: d=2 proof (LaTeX file provided); Research Notes / Proofs in the message.
highlights: Slice reduction: uniqueness in a 2D slice lifts to 3D since c_3 records the fixed coordinate (E(T) records equal coordinates).
Top-two-levels case: if every z-slice has ≤1 point, the edge between the two largest z-level vertices has a unique ℓ_z and thus unique c_3-color.
Multiplicity factorization: for a fixed representative sign vector, the number of edges with color (T,ℓ) factors as A_+(T,ℓ)·A_−(T,ℓ).
Under slice-injectivity, mixed-sign types give factors ≤1 so any realized mixed-sign edge is unique; if no mixed-sign edges exist U is a chain and a [+++]-type at the penultimate element is unique.
The same two-case strategy extends inductively to dimension d: either reduce to a (d−1)-slice or use the injective/top-two-level argument.
next_questions: Formalize and write the full inductive proof for arbitrary d (clean LaTeX writeup).
Verify corner cases rigorously where types have multiple zero coordinates (ensure c_3 bookkeeping prevents collisions).
